author: Rick Spilman
content:
It is likely that most of the oil was either burned or dispersed in the initial attack. Here is an account of the attack from one of the links in the post:

“A huge towering explosion lit up the night sky and the cargo of oil quickly caught fire and spread across the water. Residents from the Hamptons on Long Island could see the fire at sea 27 miles away and alerted the authorities. At 09.59 hours, a coup de gr√¢ce was fired from a stern torpedo tube that struck the tanker on starboard side underneath the funnel in #6 main tank and caused the ship to settle fast by the stern, striking the seafloor after five minutes.”

content: On the presumption that a gallon of the oil weighs 6.85 pounds. So far they have only recovered around 1,541 tons. Or about (just over) on fifth of the load. Good lord that is alot of sewing machine oil.
